Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: Community members pointed out that other districts have lower thresholds for remediation.
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: many of whom raised concerns two weeks ago

Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: Teachers from Frick United Academy of Language demanded to know why, if testing took place in April, fountains weren’t shut down until August.
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: from Frick United Academy of Language

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “This mistake has caused families stress, anxiety and panic, further limiting our community’s trust in this district,”

“I sincerely apologize for the stress and concern this has caused our school sites, students and families. We understand the gravity of this situation and we are fully committed to taking immediate, transparent and corrective action,”
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: District leadership — including Superintendent Kyla Johnson-Trammell

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “There is so much trust rebuilding that has to be done for our community. We have failed. And when I say ‘we’ I mean OUSD has failed at its most basic job of not poisoning our students,”
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: a sixth-grade science teacher at Frick

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “Why didn’t you do your job? You knew months ago that the water was contaminated. You didn’t act, and you let those kids come back to school and drink poisoned water,”
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: a parent at Madison Park Academy and an organizer with Communities for a Better Environment

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “This is not new to Oakland, but it is something that we need to tackle as an entire city, and we need to have community partners, philanthropic partners, as well as our county and state folks to support us in dealing with this issue,”
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: the chair of OUSD’s facilities committee

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: Alameda County recommends that any families who were notified that their schools had elevated lead levels should get their child a blood lead test.
